title: 109_hr4844
content: The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires voters to provide photo identification. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to require individuals voting in person to provide photo identification. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to require individuals voting in person to present a government-issued, current, and valid photo identification. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 now requires individuals voting in person to present a government-issued, current, and valid photo identification or proof of United States citizenship for Federal elections. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates presenting a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections. If ID is not provided, individuals can cast a provisional ballot. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections. If an individual does not present the required identification, they can cast a provisional ballot, but must provide the ID within 48 hours to be eligible to vote. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections. If an individual votes other than in person, they must submit the required identification with the ballot. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections, and individuals voting by mail must include a copy of their ID with the ballot. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections, excluding overseas military voters. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections, except for overseas military voters who are absent from the US on election day. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections, excluding overseas military voters absent on election day. An identification is considered 'government-issued' if from the Federal Government or a State, and proof of United States citizenship is required for specific identifications. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires a government-issued photo ID or proof of US citizenship for Federal elections. The identification must be issued by the Federal Government or a State and display proof of United States citizenship. Amendments to the Act include changing the heading of Section 303 to focus on providing photo identification. Amendments to the Help America Vote Act of 2002 focus on providing photo identification for Federal elections. Section 303 is updated to reflect this change. Amendments to the Help America Vote Act of 2002 require photo identification for Federal elections starting from the 2008 general election and subsequent ones. Amendments to the Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandate photo identification for Federal elections starting from the 2008 general election and all future ones. Amendments to the Help America Vote Act of 2002 require photo identification for Federal elections starting from the 2008 general election and all future ones. Making photo identifications available is emphasized in the legislation. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 amendments mandate states to provide photo identifications for Federal elections starting in 2008 and beyond. States must establish programs to offer photo IDs meeting election requirements. During fiscal year 2008 and beyond, each State must establish a program to provide free photo identifications for individuals who wish to vote but lack a government-issued ID. If a State charges a fee for this service, it must offer identifications at no cost to indigent individuals. If a State charges a fee for providing photo identification for voting, the fee must not exceed the reasonable cost to the State. Indigent individuals can receive identifications at no cost by providing an attestation of inability to afford the fee. The State cannot charge a fee for photo identification for voting if an individual attests to being unable to afford it. The identification provided cannot be used for any other government purposes. The government-issued photo identification cannot be used for any other government purposes except for voting. Payments will be made to cover the costs for states to provide photo identifications for voting to indigent individuals. The Commission will make payments to States to cover costs for providing photo identifications to individuals unable to afford fees under the program. The payment amount will be based on fees that would have been collected by the State, as determined by information provided to the Commission. The Commission will make payments to States to cover costs for providing photo identifications to individuals unable to afford fees under the program. The payment amount will be based on fees that would have been collected by the State during the year under the program, as determined by information provided to the Commission. Authorization of appropriations for payments under this part for fiscal year 2008 and beyond.
